pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:0.5: 7. The training rule on more than that
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.2: At that time the monks from the group of six said this to the monks whose robes had been stolen,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.4: a monk whose robes have been stolen or destroyed to ask an unrelated householder for a robe.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.5: You should ask for a robe.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.6: “It’s not necessary; we’ve already obtained a robe.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.9: Then the monks from the group of six went to householders and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.10: “Monks have arrived whose robes have been stolen.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.12: And they asked for many robes.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.13: Soon afterwards in the public meeting hall a man said to another,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.14: “Sir, monks have arrived whose robes have been stolen.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.16: The other replied, “I, too, have given robes.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.18: They complained and criticized those monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.19: “How can the Sakyan ascetics have no sense of moderation and ask for many robes?
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.20: Will they start up as cloth merchants or set up shop?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.21: The monks heard the complaints of those people,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.22: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized those monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.23: “How can the monks from the group of six not have any sense of moderation and ask for many robes?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.24: After rebuking those monks in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.25: “Is it true, monks, that you acted like this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.28: “… Foolish men, how can you not have any sense of moderation and ask for many robes?
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.29: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.30: And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.31.1: ‘If an unrelated male or female householder invites that monk to take many robes, he should accept at most one sarong and one upper robe. If he accepts more than that, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.2: the monk whose robes have been stolen.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.4: anyone who is not a descendant of one’s male ancestors going back seven generations, either on the mother’s side or on the father’s side.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.6: any man who lives at home.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.8: any woman who lives at home.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.12: saying, “Take as many as you like.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.13: He should accept at most one sarong and one upper robe:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.14: if three robes are destroyed, he should accept two; if two robes are destroyed, he should accept one; if one robe is destroyed, he should not accept any.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.15: If he accepts more than that:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.16: if he asks for more than that, then for the effort there is an act of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.17: When he gets the robe, it becomes subject to relinquishment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.18: The robe should be relinquished to a sangha, a group, or an individual.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.19: “And, monks, it should be relinquished like this.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.20: (To be expanded as in [Relinquishment 1](pli-tv-bu-vb-np1:3.2.5--3.2.29), with appropriate substitutions.)
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.21: ‘Venerables, this robe which I received after asking an unrelated householder for too many is to be relinquished.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.22: I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ …
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.25: ‘I give this robe back to you.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.2.1.1: If the person is unrelated and the monk perceives them as such, and he asks them for too many robes, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.2.2: If the person is unrelated, but the monk is unsure of it, and he asks them for too many robes, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.2.3: If the person is unrelated, but the monk perceives them as related, and he asks them for too many robes, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.2.4: If the person is related, but the monk perceives them as unrelated, commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.2.5: If the person is related, but the monk is unsure of it, commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.2.6: If the person is related and the monk perceives them as such, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.3.2: if he takes too much, but with the intention of returning the remainder;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.3.3: if they give, saying, “The remainder is for you;”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.3.4: if they give, but not because his robes were stolen;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.3.5: if they give, but not because his robes were destroyed;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.3.7: if it is from those who have given an invitation;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.3.8: if it is by means of his own property;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.3.10: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.3.11: The seventh rule, the training rule on more than that, is finished.
